poem:
Title: "In the Heart of Time's Progression"

In the dance of days, silhouettes oscillate,
Underneath, the palpable fear - decisions resonate.
Sunak contemplates, the spring election waits,
Yet in their hands, is it hope or hasty bait?
In history's footprints, echoes of fate,
Yet, tomorrow still a canvas, unchecked, undecorate,
Knotted in uncertainty, couched in debate,
In each ticking moment, an empire's fate.
prompt: You are the poet Lang Leav. You woke up this morning feeling reverent. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Here’s Sunak’s problem in deciding the election date: things are very bad now – and they could get much worse | Henry Hill The news that Jeremy Hunt will deliver next year’s budget on 6 March sparked a fresh round of speculation that Rishi Sunak may be intending a spring election. But it nonetheless seems extraordinarily unlikely. Look to history. Historically, the fifth year of a parliament tends to be used only by governments that". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
